subject: Re: A small note on the Unicode proposal
msgSnippet: ... I think those actually represent British pronunciation, rather than an alternate Roe.  I worked in a British school (in China) and that is how the other
messageBody:
> Concerning the modified Roe there are two examples on page
> thirteen under moor and mere. Unless Kingsley Read based the standard
> form on a dialect that pronounces "ear" as /iər/.

I think those actually represent British pronunciation, rather than an
alternate Roe. I worked in a British school (in China) and that is
how the other teachers spoke, for example "here" sounded like "he
yuh." So that Moor is "moo uh" and that Mere is "meyuh."

oliver
